Nucleotide sequence alignment of amplicons from a 440-nt region of gene 1b of Rocky Mountain bat coronaviruses compared with group 1 coronaviruses of Asian bats (BtCoVs) and human coronavirus 229E. more than 60 different RNA viruses have been isolated from and detected in bats, which play important roles in maintaining and transmitting zoonotic viruses. the need for understanding the ecology and evolution of coronaviruses in wildlife was highlighted by the observation that SARS-CoVs that caused 4 sporadic human cases of SARS in 2003–2004 were more closely related to viruses from palm civets found in 2004. persistent fecal shedding of coronaviruses has also been detected in pigs, cats, dogs, and cattle. mechanisms for persistent fecal shedding of viruses in bats without apparent disease have not yet been determined. no bat of any species occurs in both the Eastern and Western Hemispheres. rhinolophid bats are not found in the western Hemisphere and are phylogenetically far removed from the big brown bat (37,38). in our small, initial study of coronaviruses in North American bats, samples were restricted in size, location, and variety of bat species. additional bat coronaviruses with complex phylogenetic attributes, biogeographic patterns, and perhaps epizootiologic attributes may be discovered. bats could play a role in future emergence of coronaviruses in humans or other species. elucidation of their host ranges, receptor specificities, and genetic diversity will greatly aid in understanding of their potential for emergence.
